summary_snippets: Tubulin inhibitors inhibit mitosis in cancer cells by affecting the stability and dynamics of microtubules, which disrupts the mitotic spindle responsible for chromosome segregation during mitosis. This disruption leads to chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, characterized by pain, numbness, tingling sensation, and muscle weakness in limbs.
Vincristine sometimes causes chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, which can involve tingling, numbness, and hypersensitivity to cold.
Chemotherapy drugs associated with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) include vincristine, which blocks microtubule formation.
Vincristine is associated with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy and works by blocking microtubule formation.

Vincristine prevents cells from duplicating by binding to the protein tubulin. Cyclophosphamide damages DNA by binding to it and causing the formation of cross-links. Doxorubicin (also called Adriamycin) damages DNA by inserting itself between DNA bases.

summary_snippets: Romiplostim treatment is administered weekly via subcutaneous injection, with the dosage dependent on the individual's body weight and platelet count. The goal is to maintain the platelet count above 50,000 per mm3, not to achieve a normal count. If the count reaches 200,000 or higher for two consecutive weeks, the dose is reduced or treatment is suspended until the count decreases. Discontinuation of romiplostim must be approached cautiously to avoid a rapid decrease in platelet count, which may lead to bleeding diathesis.

summary_snippets: Persistent vasoocclusive disease in the kidney leads to varying degrees of renal failure in sickle cell patients, with some patients ending up on dialysis.

Sickle cell nephropathy is a type of nephropathy associated with sickle cell disease that causes kidney complications due to sickling of red blood cells in small blood vessels. This leads to local infarction (papillary necrosis) in the kidneys. Functional tubule defects in patients with sickle cell disease result from partial ischemic injury to the renal tubules.

The kidney complications of sickle cell disease include cortical infarcts leading to loss of function, persistent bloody urine, and perinephric hematomas. Papillary infarcts can lead to functional tubule abnormalities. Patients with sickle cell disease may experience a concentrating defect resulting in impaired urine concentration ability, combined with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to marked reduction in vasa recta blood flow and ischemic tubule injury.

Renal complications in sickle cell disease include hyposthenuria, hematuria, and papillary necrosis. The kidney responds to these complications by increasing blood flow and glomerular filtration rate mediated by prostaglandins. Proteinuria is present in 20–30% of patients, and nephrotic-range proteinuria is associated with progression to renal failure.

summary_snippets: Kwashiorkor is caused by inadequate protein intake in the presence of fair to good energy (calorie) intake. Typical findings include abdominal and peripheral edema due to decreased serum albumin concentration.

Kwashiorkor occurs when protein deprivation is relatively greater than the reduction in total calories. It is common in children who have early weaning and are fed a primarily carbohydrate diet. The prevalence is high in impoverished countries and can also occur in chronic diarrheal states or conditions causing protein loss.

summary_snippets: Capitation provides a fixed payment per patient per year to encourage physicians to consider a global population budget in managing individual patients and ideally reducing the use of interventions with small marginal benefit. Fee-for-service pays physicians who do more, encouraging overuse. When fees are reduced, doctors tend to increase the number of services provided to maintain revenue.

Fee-for-service incentivizes physicians to provide more treatments because payment is dependent on the quantity of care rather than quality. It raises costs and may encourage inefficiencies in care. Capitation does not incentivize physicians to perform procedures, as they are not paid extra for additional services.

summary_snippets: Undescended testes (cryptorchidism) can be brought into the scrotum in infancy by a surgical procedure called an orchiopexy to reduce the risks associated with reduced fertility, testicular germ-cell tumors, and other complications.

Orchiopexy is a surgery to move and/or permanently fix a testicle into the scrotum. It is indicated for undescended testicles, which affect 1% of males and can be bilateral in 10% of cases. Early orchiopexy reduces risks for cancer and sterility in males with cryptorchidism, which is definitively diagnosed after 1 year of age. Surgical placement into the scrotum is recommended by 18 months to decrease the likelihood of testicular cancer, testicular atrophy, and sterility.

summary_snippets: Women with recurrent miscarriage are often advised to take aspirin, and to start low molecular weight heparin treatment after missing a menstrual cycle. In pregnancy, low molecular weight heparin and low-dose aspirin are used instead of warfarin due to warfarin's teratogenicity.

All women with lupus are recommended to be screened for antiphospholipid antibodies, including the lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin antibodies. Miscarriages in the first trimester may be associated with signs of active lupus or have no known cause. Later losses are primarily associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, despite treatment with heparin and aspirin.

Aspirin has no effect in preventing recurrent miscarriage in women with unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss. There are currently no treatments for women with unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss. Each additional loss worsens the prognosis for a successful pregnancy. There is one drug in development, NT100, for the treatment of unexplained recurrent miscarriage.

summary_snippets: Maraviroc is a negative allosteric modulator of the CCR5 receptor, which is essential for the entry of most HIV strains into host cells. It binds to CCR5, blocking the HIV protein gp120 from associating with the receptor, preventing HIV from entering human macrophages and T cells. An HIV tropism test, such as a trofile assay, must be performed to determine if the drug will be effective, as HIV can also use other coreceptors like CXCR4.

Maraviroc is a CCR5 antagonist that interferes with HIV binding at the stage of co-receptor engagement. A co-receptor tropism assay should be performed to ensure that the potential patient is only harboring R5 viruses.
Maraviroc binds specifically and selectively to the host protein CCR5, which is one of the two chemokine receptors necessary for the entrance of HIV into CD4+ cells.

Maraviroc is a CCR5 antagonist effective only against CCR5-tropic HIV viruses. A phenotypic assay, such as the Trofile assay, is necessary to determine the co-receptor tropism of the virus, indicating whether it is CCR5-tropic or CXCR4-tropic.

summary_snippets: Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction that develops over several days and is cell-mediated rather than antibody-mediated. It involves the interaction of T cells, monocytes, and macrophages. CD4+ Th1 cells recognize foreign antigens in complex with MHC class II on antigen-presenting cells, such as macrophages. These cells secrete IL-12, stimulating the proliferation of further CD4+ Th1 cells. Activated CD4+ T cells secrete IL-2 and interferon gamma (IFNγ) to mediate the immune response.
Type IV hypersensitivity involves the overreaction of helper T cells and overproduction of cytokines, which can damage tissues, cause inflammation, and lead to cell death.

summary_snippets: Hydroxyurea is used in the treatment of sickle cell disease by reactivating fetal hemoglobin production in place of hemoglobin S. This action decreases the number and severity of attacks and may increase survival time in patients.

Fetal hemoglobin, when produced at higher levels after birth, can decrease the number of painful episodes in patients with sickle-cell disease and improves prognosis. This is due to fetal hemoglobin's ability to disrupt the formation of hemoglobin S chains within red blood cells.
Hydroxycarbamide, also known as hydroxyurea, is used in sickle-cell disease to increase fetal hemoglobin and decrease the number of attacks. It is believed to work by blocking the making of DNA.

summary_snippets: The defining sign of kwashiorkor is pitting edema, particularly swelling of the hands and feet. Kwashiorkor is characterized by an enlarged fatty liver, fibrosis, and dysfunction of several organs such as the liver, kidneys, and nervous system. Other signs include a distended abdomen, thinning of hair, loss of teeth, skin or hair depigmentation, and dermatitis. Children with kwashiorkor often exhibit irritability and anorexia.

Marasmus is characterized by severe malnutrition and energy deficiency, with body weight reduced to less than 62% of the normal for age. It typically occurs in children and is associated with inadequate energy intake in all forms, including protein. In contrast to marasmus, kwashiorkor involves protein deficiency with adequate energy intake, often leading to edema and ascites. The clinical signs of kwashiorkor generally include pitting edema, particularly in the ankles and around the eyes, along with abdominal swelling.

Kwashiorkor is caused by inadequate protein intake in the presence of fair to good energy (calorie) intake. Typical findings in a patient with kwashiorkor include abdominal and peripheral edema, which is due to a decreased serum albumin concentration. Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height can be normal because of edema. Treatment includes a diet adequate in calories and protein.

Kwashiorkor is a severe form of malnutrition associated with a deficiency in dietary protein, causing an osmotic imbalance in the gastrointestinal system that leads to swelling (edema). It can result from inadequate nutrition, especially in contexts like displacement, where food supply is unreliable. The condition is characterized by symptoms such as pitting edema, abdominal swelling (ascites), irritability, and drowsiness in affected individuals.

summary_snippets: Parvovirus infection in pregnant women is associated with hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, sometimes leading to miscarriage or stillbirth. The risk of fetal loss is about 10% if infection occurs before pregnancy week 20, especially between weeks 14 and 20.

It can lead to hydrops fetalis secondary to fetal anemia. Miscarriage, stillbirth, fetal anemia, hepatic failure, and abnormal neurodevelopment outcomes are possible serious complications of parvovirus B19 in pregnancy, although they are rare.

Infection with parvovirus B19 in pregnant women during the first trimester has been linked to hydrops fetalis and spontaneous miscarriage. summary_snippets: Flutamide acts as a selective antagonist of the androgen receptor (AR), competing with androgens like testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT) for binding to ARs in tissues such as the prostate gland. By doing so, it prevents their effects and stops them from stimulating prostate cancer cells to grow. Flutamide is a prodrug to a more active form and has largely been replaced by newer and improved non-steroidal anti-androgens (NSAAs) like bicalutamide and enzalutamide.

Flutamide blocks androgens, such as DHT and testosterone, to provide treatment for prostate cancer. It is used alongside GnRH agonists to prevent an initial surge in androgen activity and is classified as a non-steroidal anti-androgen (NSAA).
Flutamide and bicalutamide are antiandrogens that bind and inhibit the androgen receptor, blocking the effects of testosterone on certain prostate cancers.

Flutamide is a pure nonsteroidal antiandrogen approved for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer. Its mechanism of action is inhibition of nuclear binding of androgens in target tissues. Flutamide is considered to belong to the same class of drugs as those that block the androgen receptor.

summary_snippets: Neutrophil defects typically present in the first several months of life. A history of recurrent bacterial infections in a 6-month-old boy could suggest an immunodeficiency disorder. The presence of large cytoplasmic vacuoles in neutrophils may indicate a specific condition. A mutation in the LYST gene is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency-1 (LAD1) is characterized by life-threatening, recurrent bacterial or fungal soft tissue infections, often apparent at birth. Common symptoms include omphalitis, delayed separation of the umbilical cord, periodontal disease, elevated neutrophils, and impaired wound healing. The disorder does not increase vulnerability to viral infections or cancer.

In patients with Chediak–Higashi syndrome, abnormal giant lysosomes and granules accumulate in T lymphocytes, myeloid cells, platelets, and melanocytes. They suffer from severe, recurrent infections due to defective killing of intracellular and extracellular pathogens, as well as defective cytolytic activity of CTLs and NK cells. Physical examination findings include light-colored skin and silver-colored hair. Affected children's neutrophils reveal large cytoplasmic vacuoles.

summary_snippets: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive syndrome characterized by atopic dermatitis. The diagnosis requires evidence of itchy skin (or parental report of scratching or rubbing) plus three or more of the following: history of involvement of skin creases, history of asthma or allergic rhinitis (or history of atopic disease in a first-degree relative if the child is <4 years of age), history of generally dry skin in the past year, onset in a child <2 years of age (criterion not used if the child is <4 years of age), and visible flexural dermatitis.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked disorder characterized by eczema, increased IgE/IgA, decreased IgM, and thrombocytopenia. The classic presentation includes bleeding, eczema, and recurrent otitis media. Patients are at increased risk of atopic disorders, lymphoma/leukemia, and infections from bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Haemophilus influenzae type b.

summary_snippets: Preeclampsia can be diagnosed if a woman has both increased blood pressure and one or more signs of significant organ damage. Risk factors for preeclampsia include a history of preeclampsia in a sibling.

The main diagnostic criteria of HELLP syndrome include hepatic dysfunction, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in patients suspected to have preeclampsia. Thrombocytopenia is indicated by a low platelet count (below 100 x 10^9 L^-1). Elevated serum levels of LDH, ALT, and AST are indicative of hepatic dysfunction, with significantly high levels correlating with increased maternal mortality risk. A history of preeclampsia in siblings is also noted as a risk factor for the condition.

summary_snippets: Mothers who are Rh negative and have anti-D antibodies need to determine the fetus's Rh antigen. If the fetus is Rh positive, the anti-D antibodies can pose a risk.

RhD negative mothers are recommended to receive RhD immune globulin (RhIG) at about 28 weeks gestation, especially if they may be exposed to Rh positive blood from the baby. This is to prevent the development of anti-D antibodies.

A Rh-negative mother may produce IgG blood group antibodies if she has a child with a Rh-positive father and the fetus is Rh-positive. This can lead to Rh disease or hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). If a pregnant woman is known to have anti-D antibodies, testing the Rh blood type of the fetus can assess the risk of Rh disease.

In the United States, anti-D immune globulin is given prophylactically to all D-negative, unsensitized women at approximately 28 weeks' gestation. A second dose is given after delivery if the newborn is D-positive. Administration of immune globulin is recommended only after the newborn is confirmed to be D positive. If immune globulin is inadvertently not administered following delivery, it should be given as soon as the omission is recognized, as there may be some protection up to 28 days postpartum.

summary_snippets: Adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder is characterized by restricted range of motion in all planes of movement, both active and passive. It often occurs in patients with systemic diseases, including diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for the condition.

Adhesive capsulitis or frozen shoulder syndrome is a common shoulder capsule pathology resulting from injury, surgery, or chronic health conditions such as diabetes. It leads to inflammation of the shoulder capsule, causing stiffness, pain, and limited range of motion. Treatment may involve heat, NSAIDs, light stretching, and physical therapy. In severe cases, arthroscopic surgery may be needed to release thickened scar tissue.

summary_snippets: According to the WHO criteria revised in 2000, a rise in cardiac troponin accompanied by typical symptoms or changes in ECG is diagnostic of myocardial infarction. The rise and fall of serum cardiac biomarkers, such as creatine kinase-MB fraction and troponin, are important for diagnosing myocardial infarction.

CK-MB is not as specific as troponins for acute myocardial injury and may be elevated with past cardiac surgery, inflammation, or electrical cardioversion. Additionally, it rises within 4–8 hours and returns to normal within 2–3 days. Copeptin may be useful to rule out myocardial infarction rapidly when used along with troponin.

The markers most widely used in the detection of myocardial infarction (MI) are the MB subtype of creatine kinase and cardiac troponins T and I, as they are more specific for myocardial injury. Cardiac troponins T and I are released within 4–6 hours of an MI attack and remain elevated for up to 2 weeks, providing nearly complete tissue specificity for assessing myocardial damage. Elevated troponins in the setting of chest pain may predict a high likelihood of a myocardial infarction in the near future.

summary_snippets: Chancroid is a lesion typical of infection with the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancroid lesions are typically painful and have a grey or yellow purulent exudate. They have a soft edge and are associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

The most common causes of genital ulcers in the United States are herpes simplex infections and syphilis, with herpes simplex being the most prevalent. Important signs associated with genital ulcers include painful or non-painful ulcers and the presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the groin.

Chancroid is a lesion typical of infection with the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancres, which are caused by Treponema pallidum (the bacteria that causes syphilis), are typically painless, while chancroid lesions are painful. Chancroid lesions typically have a soft base with undermined edges and cause regional unilateral lymph node enlargement.

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, characterized by painful sores on the genitalia that start as an erythematous papular lesion that breaks down into a painful bleeding ulcer with a necrotic base. It is associated with painful ulcers and can cause unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Patients with mesothelioma present with chest pain and shortness of breath. The chest radiograph reveals a pleural effusion and generalized pleural thickening.

Malignant pleural effusion is a condition where cancer causes fluid to collect between the pleura lining the lungs and chest cavity. Lung cancer and breast cancer are the most common causes of malignant pleural effusions. Other common causes include pleural mesothelioma and lymphoma. Symptoms that may predict a malignant pleural effusion diagnosis include symptoms lasting more than 1 month and the absence of fever.

summary_snippets: Primary prophylaxis for variceal hemorrhage in patients with cirrhosis includes routine screening by endoscopy and treatment with nonselective beta blockers, such as propranolol or nadolol, or through variceal band ligation. Beta blockers have been shown to lower the risk of variceal hemorrhage and decrease mortality related to variceal bleeding.

Non-selective β-blockers (e.g., propranolol, timolol, nadolol) are preferred for reducing the risk of bleeding from esophageal varices due to their ability to decrease cardiac output and splanchnic blood flow. However, they do not prevent the formation of esophageal varices. When there are medical contraindications to beta-blockers, prophylactic endoscopic variceal ligation is often performed.

Non-selective beta blockers, such as propranolol and nadolol, are used to decrease the pressure of the portal vein in patients with esophageal varices and have been shown to regress portal hypertensive gastropathy.

summary_snippets: Osteosarcoma often is located at the epiphysis or metaphysis of anatomic sites that are associated with maximum growth velocity (distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus). It presents with pain and may be associated with a palpable mass. Radiographs of the affected region usually reveal a lytic lesion, often associated with calcification in the soft tissue surrounding the lesion. Ewing sarcoma can occur in almost any bone in the body, with the femur and pelvis being the most common sites. Clinical manifestations may include local pain and swelling, systemic symptoms such as fever and weight loss.

Ewing sarcoma accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors and is the second most common bone sarcoma in children. It primarily affects individuals under 20 years of age, with boys being slightly more affected than girls and a predilection for Caucasians. The tumors generally arise in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, with 20% being extraskeletal. Symptoms include painful enlarging masses that are frequently tender, warm, and swollen. Radiographs of Ewing sarcoma show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins extending into surrounding soft tissues, and there is a characteristic periosteal reaction that deposits layers of reactive bone in an onion-skin fashion.

Oligohydramnios is associated with complications such as cord compression, abnormal heart rate, fetal acidosis, and meconium amniotic fluid. These tumors can be diagnosed through the presence of these structures.

summary_snippets: Colesevelam binds bile acids in the intestine, impeding their reabsorption. It can increase the demand for cholesterol in the liver cells, resulting in increased clearance of LDL-C from the blood. However, it is important to separate the timing of colesevelam dosing from other medications due to its mechanism of action.

Colesevelam is a bile acid sequestrant indicated for reducing elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) in patients with primary hyperlipidemia and for improving glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is important to note that the timing of the dosing of colesevelam should be separated from other medications, as it can affect the absorption of those medications.

Colesevelam is a bile acid binding resin that functions by binding bile acids, increasing their excretion, and is useful for decreasing LDL cholesterol. The most common side effects include bloating and diarrhea.

summary_snippets: The rotator cuff tear involves injury to one or more of the tendons or muscles of the rotator cuff, which consists of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis. The supraspinatus is the most commonly affected tendon. Symptoms of a rotator cuff tear may include shoulder pain, weakness, and difficulty with movement, particularly in external rotation and abduction.

For the diagnosis of a full-thickness rotator cuff tear, key tests include the painful arc sign, weakness in external rotation, and the drop arm sign (Codman's test), where the arm is raised to 90° and drops suddenly or causes pain when attempting to lower it.

summary_snippets: Subcutaneous nodules occur as painless, small (0.5–2 cm), mobile lumps beneath the skin over bony prominences, particularly of the hands, feet, elbows, and occasionally the vertebrae. They are commonly associated with carditis. Fever occurs in most cases of ARF, although rarely in cases of pure chorea.

Subcutaneous nodules are firm, painless, nonpruritic, mobile nodules found on the extensor surfaces of large and small joints. Chorea (Sydenham chorea) consists of neurologic and psychiatric signs and is often present long after the infection.

The most common clinical finding in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a migratory arthritis involving multiple joints. One of the minor Jones Criteria includes subcutaneous nodules. The presence of involuntary, purposeless movement known as Sydenham chorea is also associated with ARF.

summary_snippets: Clozapine is usually used for individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia who have had an inadequate response to other antipsychotics or have been unable to tolerate other drugs due to extrapyramidal side effects. It is regarded as the gold-standard treatment when other medication has been insufficiently effective. Clozapine treatment has been demonstrated to produce improved outcomes in multiple domains, including a reduced risk of hospitalization, reduced risk of drug discontinuation, and improved efficacy in treating positive psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia.

Clozapine is prescribed for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, which is the failure to respond to two or more antipsychotic medications. Clozapine has a risk of agranulocytosis, requiring blood tests for the first six months of treatment.

Clozapine is an effective treatment for those who respond poorly to other drugs ("treatment-resistant" or "refractory" schizophrenia), but it has the potentially serious side effect of agranulocytosis (lowered white blood cell count) in less than 4% of people.
Clozapine can cause agranulocytosis (a decreased number of white blood cells), requiring blood monitoring for the patient.

summary_snippets: C1-inhibitor deficiency is associated with hereditary angioedema, which presents as recurrent episodes of swelling in the face, mouth, and/or airway that can occur spontaneously or in response to minimal triggers. The condition is characterized by low levels of C1-inhibitor in 85% of cases, while 15% involve dysfunctional but normal levels of the protein. The symptoms typically resolve in 2 to 3 days.

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) should be considered in patients with recurrent angioedema without urticaria, recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and vomiting, and a positive family history of angioedema. C1-inhibitor levels are low in HAE, particularly in type I, which is responsible for approximately 80–85% of cases. Low C1 inhibitor (C1-INH) functional levels are essential for diagnosis.

summary_snippets: Bacillus anthracis is a Gram-positive, spore-forming rod that produces anthrax toxin, which consists of protective antigen, lethal factor, and edema factor. It has a polypeptide capsule made of poly d-glutamate, which is a virulence factor that contributes to its survival in host tissue. Pulmonary anthrax can present with flu-like symptoms that rapidly progress to fever, pulmonary hemorrhage, mediastinitis, and shock, and is associated with inhalation of spores often from contaminated animal products.
The lethality of anthrax is due to the poly-D-glutamic acid capsule, which protects the bacterium from phagocytosis by host neutrophils.

summary_snippets: Patients with third-and fourth-degree lacerations at delivery are associated with an increased risk of fecal incontinence (odds ratio [OR] 3.09). Approximately one-third of patients with occult anal sphincter tears have symptoms of anal incontinence. Forceps-assisted vaginal delivery significantly increases the risk of anal incontinence, while the data on vacuum-assisted delivery are less conclusive.

Among women who experience a third or fourth degree perineal tear, 60-80% are asymptomatic after 12 months. Faecal incontinence, faecal urgency, chronic perineal pain, pain with sex, and fistula formation occur in a minority of women, but may be permanent.

summary_snippets: In diabetes mellitus type 2, there is an accumulation of amyloid in the pancreatic islets, which likely disrupts their anatomy and physiology. The pathogenesis involves a reduced population of islet beta-cells, reduced secretory function of the surviving beta-cells, and peripheral tissue insulin resistance. Type 2 diabetes is characterized by increased glucagon secretion that is unresponsive to blood glucose levels.

summary_snippets: Zenker diverticulum can present with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and halitosis (smelly breath). Food might get trapped in the outpouching, leading to regurgitation.

Zenker diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal false diverticulum caused by esophageal dysmotility, resulting in herniation of mucosal tissue at Killian triangle. Presenting symptoms include dysphagia, obstruction, gurgling, aspiration, and foul breath (halitosis). It is most common in elderly males.

Zenker’s diverticulum typically occurs in elderly patients and is associated with dysphagia, regurgitation of particulate food debris, aspiration, and halitosis. The pathogenesis involves stenosis of the cricopharyngeus, leading to increased hypopharyngeal pressure during swallowing and the development of a pulsion diverticulum above the cricopharyngeus. A cricopharyngeal bar is related to Zenker’s diverticulum, as it involves limited distensibility of the cricopharyngeus.

Zenker’s diverticula result from increased intraluminal pressure associated with distal obstruction, specifically from a stenotic cricopharyngeus muscle. Symptoms of Zenker’s diverticula can include dysphagia and halitosis.

They account for less than 1% of all breast neoplasms and predominantly occur in adult women, most commonly between the ages of 40 and 50. Patients with phyllodes tumors typically present with a firm, palpable mass that can increase in size within a few weeks.

summary_snippets: Clomipramine is a reuptake inhibitor of serotonin and norepinephrine, specifically blocking their reuptake into neurons, which increases their extracellular concentrations in the synaptic cleft and results in increased serotonergic and noradrenergic neurotransmission.
The antidepressant effects of clomipramine are thought to be due to reuptake inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine.

Clomipramine is an antidepressant that is used to treat clinical depression and is effective for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). It decreases the breakdown of serotonin and norepinephrine by blocking their reuptake, thereby increasing their levels in the synaptic cleft.
Clomipramine is an antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine, resulting in higher concentrations of these neurotransmitters in the brain.

summary_snippets: People with Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) often experience weakness that is less severe than expected based on symptoms, with strength improving on repeated testing, such as improvement of power on repeated hand grip, known as "Lambert's sign." Reflexes are typically reduced at rest, but increase with muscle use, which is characteristic of LEMS. Sluggish pupillary light reflex may also be observed. Disruption of the autonomic nervous system in LEMS can lead to symptoms such as dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, impaired sweating, and orthostatic hypotension.

summary_snippets: The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) is the main central connection for the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and abducens nerve. Lesions of the MLF can cause diplopia, which may be associated with conditions such as multiple sclerosis, a neoplasm, or a stroke.

A lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus produces slowed or absent adduction of the ipsilateral eye upon contralateral gaze and is usually associated with involuntary jerky eye movements (nystagmus) of the abducting eye, a syndrome known as internuclear ophthalmoplegia. This can occur due to demyelination of the axons in conditions like multiple sclerosis, presenting as nystagmus and diplopia.

The medial longitudinal fasciculus carries information about the direction that the eyes should move. It connects the nuclei of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the abducens nerve (CN VI). It is integral to saccadic eye movements and vestibulo-ocular reflex.

summary_snippets: The diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid includes clinical assessment, skin biopsy for histopathology, and direct immunofluorescence. Direct immunofluorescence is the gold standard for diagnosis. Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by blistering skin disease, particularly in patients over 70 years old, with tense blisters and erosions occurring without another identifiable cause. Typical histopathologic findings include the presence of linear deposits of C3 and IgG along the basement membrane on direct immunofluorescence.

Diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid consists of at least 2 positive results out of 3 criteria: (1) pruritus and/or predominant cutaneous blisters, (2) linear IgG and/or C3c deposits by direct immunofluorescence microscopy on a skin biopsy specimen, and (3) positive epidermal side staining by indirect immunofluorescence microscopy on human salt-split skin.

summary_snippets: Aortic stenosis presents with a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the upper right sternal border, which radiates to the carotid arteries. The murmur is accentuated by squatting and decreases with standing and the Valsalva maneuver. The intensity of the murmur increases with the severity of stenosis, and the peak occurs later in the crescendo-decrescendo profile as the stenosis becomes more severe.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by hypertrophy of the interventricular septum causing outflow obstruction of the left ventricle. It commonly presents with dyspnea and chest pain during daily activities and may lead to syncope. Physical examination findings include a loud systolic murmur and a palpable triple apical impulse due to a palpable presystolic fourth heart sound.

summary_snippets: Consistent condom use reduces the risk of HIV transmission by approximately 80% over the long term. When condoms are used consistently by a couple in which one person is infected, the rate of HIV infection is less than 1% per year. Bacterial infections leading to gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis can be prevented by sexual abstinence, use of barrier contraception such as condoms, pre-exposure vaccination (HPV and Hepatitis B vaccines), and reducing the number of sexual partners.

Consistent and correct use of male latex condoms can reduce the risk of STD transmission. Inconsistent use can lead to STD acquisition because transmission can occur with a single act of intercourse. The most reliable ways to avoid transmission of STDs are to abstain from sexual activity or to be in a long-term mutually monogamous relationship with an uninfected partner.

summary_snippets: Anti-endomysial (EMA) antibodies of the immunoglobulin A (IgA) type can detect coeliac disease with high sensitivity and specificity, especially in patients with villous atrophy. Serology for anti-transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG) has a sensitivity of 99% and specificity of over 90%. Both antibodies have high sensitivity to diagnose individuals with classic symptoms and complete villous atrophy.

The diagnosis of celiac disease requires the detection of characteristic histologic changes on small-intestinal biopsy, including an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes, absence or a reduced height of villi, which causes a flat appearance, increased crypt cell proliferation resulting in crypt hyperplasia, and loss of villous structure. Positive immunological assays for anti-transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies can also indicate celiac disease.

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG or anti-TG2) are found in patients with several conditions, including celiac disease. In celiac disease, ATA are involved in the destruction of the villous extracellular matrix and target the destruction of intestinal villous epithelial cells by killer cells.

summary_snippets: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is an inflammatory autoimmune disease of large blood vessels, which can lead to complications such as blockage of the artery to the eye resulting in blindness, aortic dissection, and aortic aneurysm. The underlying mechanism involves inflammation of small blood vessels within larger arteries, mainly affecting arteries around the head and neck, but some in the chest may also be involved. Symptoms include headaches, pain over the temples, flu-like symptoms, double vision, and difficulty opening the mouth. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy of the temporal artery, which may show transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina.

summary_snippets: A normal T score is -1.0 and above, low bone density is between -1.0 and -2.5, and osteoporosis is -2.5 and lower. The patient’s condition of osteopenia would correspond to a T score between -1.0 and -2.5.

Osteoporosis is defined in women by the World Health Organization as a bone mineral density of 2.5 standard deviations below peak bone mass. Osteopenia is a condition where bone mineral density is lower than normal but not low enough to be classified as osteoporosis. DEXA scans are used to measure bone mineral density, and results are often expressed as T-scores, with a T-score between -1 and -2.5 indicating osteopenia.

Bone density between 1 and 2.5 standard deviations below the reference, or a T-score between −1.0 and −2.5, indicates osteopenia. The ISCD recommends using Caucasian women between 20 and 29 years old as the baseline for bone density for all patients. The ISCD recommends that Z-scores, not T-scores, be used to classify bone density in premenopausal women and men under 50.

summary_snippets: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) most often first manifests as inflammation of particular finger or toe joints, however, pain and swelling of larger joints, including the knees, may also be the first sign. Reactive arthritis often presents with lower limb oligoarthritis, including that of the knee. Gouty arthritis is characterized by arthritis of a single joint of the lower extremities with rapid onset, and while the knee may be affected, skin symptoms occur less often.

Dermatomyositis is characterized by skin rashes and muscle weakness. Symptoms include purplish or lilac rashes around the eyes (heliotrope) and "shawl" rashes on the neck and upper chest, as well as red or violet papules (Gottron's sign) on finger joints and bony prominences. These rashes can be worsened by sunlight exposure and may be itchy, painful, and may bleed.

Psoriatic arthritis occurs in 5-10% of patients who have psoriasis. The classic presentation involves the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, with symptoms such as morning stiffness, deformity of involved joints, dactylitis, and nail involvement. Well-demarcated red plaques with silvery scaling are characteristic lesions of psoriasis.

Empagliflozin is used in combination with diet and exercise to help lower blood sugar levels in people with type 2 diabetes. It can be used alongside other medications like metformin. summary_snippets: B12 deficiency, also known as hypocobalaminemia, often results from absorption complications and is commonly associated with pernicious anemia. This autoimmune disorder destroys cells that produce intrinsic factor, hindering B12 absorption. B12 deficiency can lead to symptoms of anemia, such as pale skin, dizziness, and fatigue.

summary_snippets: Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and therefore should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant primarily used to support smoking cessation. It carries a much higher risk of seizure than many other antidepressants, and extreme caution must be taken in patients with a history of seizure disorder.

summary_snippets: The blood smear of a person with iron-deficiency anemia shows many hypochromic (pale, relatively colorless) and small red blood cells, and may also show poikilocytosis (variation in shape) and anisocytosis (variation in size). With more severe iron-deficiency anemia, the peripheral blood smear may show hypochromic, pencil-shaped cells and, occasionally, small numbers of nucleated red blood cells. The platelet count may be slightly above the high limit of normal in iron-deficiency anemia (termed a mild thrombocytosis), but severe cases can present with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).

summary_snippets: Avoiding foods that are high in fat and high in oxalate (such as nuts, pepper, chocolate, rhubarb, spinach, dark green vegetables, and fruits) can help reduce hyperoxaluria (excessive urinary excretion of oxalate). Reducing the amount of meats and other purine-containing foods suppresses hyperuricosuria (increased amounts of uric acid in the urine). Increasing fluid intake will increase urine volume and dilute the stone-forming salts to below the upper risk levels.

Aside from vigorous oral hydration and eating more dietary calcium, other prevention strategies for kidney stones include avoidance of large doses of supplemental and restriction of oxalate-rich foods such as leaf vegetables, rhubarb, soy products, and chocolate. Some evidence indicates magnesium intake decreases the risk of symptomatic kidney stones.

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones include higher urine calcium, higher urine oxalate, and lower urine citrate. Increasing urine volume to at least 2 L/day can reduce the likelihood of crystal formation.

Broad casts describe the wider cast product of a dilated duct, which is also present in chronic kidney failure.

summary_snippets: Circulating oxalate can complex with plasma calcium, reducing the ionized calcium. Therapy must be initiated in patients with severe metabolic acidosis and elevated anion and osmolar gaps. Other diagnostic features, such as hypocalcemia or acute renal failure with crystalluria, can provide important confirmation for urgent, empiric therapy.

Large anion gap acidosis is usually present during the initial stage of ethylene glycol poisoning. The diagnosis should be considered in any people with severe acidosis. Urine microscopy can reveal needle or envelope-shaped calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

A vitamin with iron may also be used.

This means that the gene associated with this disorder is located on the X chromosome and only a single mutation is needed to cause the disorder in males.

summary_snippets: Mefloquine is the only drug advised for pregnant women traveling to areas with drug-resistant malaria; it is generally considered safe in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. Chloroquine and proguanil are regarded as safe for use in pregnancy.

Doxycycline (100 mg daily) is an effective alternative for pre-exposure prophylaxis against malaria and is generally well tolerated but cannot be used by children <8 years old or by pregnant women. Chloroquine is no longer reliable for preventing P. falciparum infections in most areas but is used for other human Plasmodium species and for P. falciparum malaria in certain Central American countries.

Doxycycline and the combination of atovaquone/proguanil (Malarone) are frequently used for prevention of malaria and are better tolerated. Mefloquine is taken once a week but may not be as well tolerated. Areas with chloroquine-sensitive malaria are uncommon.

Mefloquine is used for the prevention of malaria in areas without resistant parasites and is recommended by the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as a first or second-line agent for malaria prophylaxis, depending on resistance patterns. It is typically taken for one to two weeks before entering an area with malaria.

summary_snippets: Exenatide is believed to facilitate glucose control by increasing insulin secretion from the pancreas in response to meals, suppressing the pancreatic release of glucagon, and slowing gastric emptying. However, it is indicated for patients who can produce some insulin, as type 1 diabetes results in insufficient insulin production.

Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1 receptor agonist) that increases insulin release from the pancreas and decreases excessive glucagon release. It is used to treat diabetes mellitus type 2, but the document does not indicate its effectiveness or appropriateness for patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus. Common side effects include low blood sugar, nausea, dizziness, abdominal pain, and pain at the site of injection.

summary_snippets: Lichen sclerosus is the most common white lesion of the vulva, often occurring in postmenopausal women and prepubertal girls. Symptoms include pruritus, dyspareunia, and burning. It is characterized by decreased subcutaneous fat, atrophic vulva with small or absent labia minora, obliteration of anatomic landmarks, thin labia majora, and sometimes phimosis. The surface appears pale with a shiny, crinkled pattern and may have fissures and excoriation. The lesions are typically symmetric and can extend to perineal and perianal areas. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and there is an association between invasive cancer and lichen sclerosus, although the causation is unclear.

Lichen sclerosus is characterized by thinning of the epidermis, disappearance of rete pegs, acellular dermal fibrosis, and a bandlike mononuclear inflammatory cell infiltrate. It appears as smooth, white plaques or papules, and, when the entire vulva is affected, the labia become atrophic and stiffened. Symptoms include severe vulvar itching, pain during vaginal intercourse, and the presence of dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions. It occurs most commonly in postmenopausal women and prepubertal girls.

It is given as an adjunct to levodopa and acts by inhibiting COMT in the periphery, leading to increased plasma levels of levodopa and more constant dopaminergic stimulation.

summary_snippets: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome occurs primarily in young children due to a toxin-producing strain of Staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an abrupt fever and a diffused sunburned appearance of the rash, associated with tenderness and large blister formation that easily pop, leading to skin peeling. The rash can resemble scarlet fever but the affected skin is tender.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) presents with the widespread formation of fluid-filled blisters that are thin-walled and easily ruptured, along with a positive Nikolsky's sign. The syndrome also includes widespread painful erythroderma, often involving the face and diaper areas, and extensive areas of desquamation. SSSS spares the mucous membranes and is most common in children under 6 years but can occur in adults who are immunosuppressed or have kidney failure.

summary_snippets: The diagnosis of COPD is made when the FEV1/FVC ratio is less than 0.7 or the FEV1 is less than 75% of predicted. The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease criteria require that values are measured after bronchodilator medication. According to the European Respiratory Society criteria, COPD is defined when a patient's FEV1% is less than 88% of the predicted value for men, or less than 89% for women.
